messageBody:
Thanks,
That makes sense. I figured I was doing something wrong. I got the
technique of putting the verify in the tearDown from either an online
tutorial or a book I read somewhere. If I find it I'll list it here.
I'm really brand new at all of this and I'm trying to make sense of it
all. I got the JUnit in action book and read the chapter in XDoclet in
action regarding mock objects. So now that's what I'm using. I use
XDoclet to design the mocks for the objects my code interacts with.
I'll take a look at JMock to see how it compares. I am a little
disenchanted due to the lack of documentation on the mockobjectdoclet
task. I'll be posting back here no doubt. Thanx all.

Cliff
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Steve Freeman <steve@m...> wrote:
> First. Consider moving to jmock (www.jmock.org). That's our current
> favourite.
>
> You shouldn't call verify() in the tearDown, it's just the same as
> calling Assert. The test is over by the time you get to tearDown(), so
> failures won't be logged properly. In jMock, we've subclassed TestCase
> to collect mocks and call verify() automatically in the right place.
>
> S.
>
> cliftonccraig wrote:
> > I new to this and I'm not even sure I'm posting to the right list or
> > not but here goes. I just started using JUnit and TDD on this project
> > I'm working on. I am using MockObjects (I believe .9 version) through
> > XDoclet to create a mock of an interface that the object I'm testing
> > uses. What I noticed is that introducing the call to mock.verify() in
> > the TestCase tearDown method masks exceptions that are thrown from
> > test methods. In other words if an unexpected exception occurs in a
> > test method it doesn't appear to show in the logs when the
> > mock.verify() executes. Mind you, I am using the JUnit support out of
> > IntelliJ Idea. However I don't think that is relevant to the problem.
> > The basics of my TestCase are as follows.
> > class MyTestCase
> > {
> > private MyMock mock;
> >
> > public void testMyMethod() throws UnExcpectedException
> > {
> > //Test logic here
> > }
> > public void setup()
> > {
> > mock = new MyMock();
> > //logic to set mock preconditions and expectations...
> > }
> > public void verify()
> > {
> > //This executes and thorws an exception that masks the real
> > exception in the test method.
> > mock.verify();
> > }
> > }
> > When I don't use mocks then I can test and figure out problems rather
> > easily because I propogate exceptions up to the JUnit framework where
> > the UI catches them and displays them accordingly. I'm not sure if
> > this is the best practice which is why I'm writing. Could someone
> > guide me here?
